author: Gazeta do Povo
title: Irmão de Gilmar Mendes declara patrimônio milionário ao TSE
text:
Candidato à prefeitura de Diamantino (MT), Chico Mendes (União Brasil) - irmão do ministro do Supremo Tribunal Federal (STF) Gilmar Mendes - declarou à Justiça Eleitoral possuir um patrimônio de R$ 56,4 milhões. Veterinário, Chico Mendes tem 56 anos e tenta se eleger pela terceira vez como prefeito da cidade, que tem 21,9 mil habitantes. Ele já comandou o município por dois mandatos, entre os anos 2000 e 2008. No pleito de outubro, conta com o apoio do ex-presidente Jair Bolsonaro (PL).
Na declaração ao Tribunal Superior Eleitoral (TSE), Mendes apresentou como bem de maior valor 50% de um área de terra rural de 1.016 hectares, em Diamantino. O terreno é avaliado em R$ 9,2 milhões. Ele declarou, ainda, ter parte de outros quatro terrenos, sendo um deles de R$ 1 milhão.
Na lista de patrimônios, há R$ 452 mil em carros e moto, um apartamento avaliado em 600 mil e uma casa também com valor de R$ 600 mil, além de 50% da quota de 2.442 cabeças de bovinos, de R$ 1,9 milhão.
No site da Justiça Eleitoral, é possível encontrar os dados do candidato na eleição de 2004. Na época, ele afirmou que não tinha bens a declarar. Não há dados da eleição de 2000 no sistema.

author: ABMN Staff
title: Wells Fargo & Company Cuts Vital Energy (NYSE:VTLE) Price Target to $24.00 - American Banking and Market News
text: Vital Energy ( NYSE:VTLE – Get Free Report ) had its price target lowered by Wells Fargo & Company from $36.00 to $24.00 in a research report issued to clients and investors on Tuesday, Benzinga reports. The brokerage currently has an “equal weight” rating on the stock. Wells Fargo & Company ‘s price objective would indicate a potential upside of 6.79% from the company’s current price.A number of other analysts also recently issued reports on the stock. Piper Sandler dropped their price objective on shares of Vital Energy from $32.00 to $24.00 and set a “neutral” rating for the company in a report on Thursday, March 6th. Mizuho upped their price target on shares of Vital Energy from $37.00 to $38.00 and gave the company a “neutral” rating in a report on Tuesday, January 14th. Williams Trading set a $27.00 price target on shares of Vital Energy in a report on Wednesday, March 5th. Raymond James decreased their price objective on shares of Vital Energy from $44.00 to $30.00 and set an “outperform” rating on the stock in a research report on Monday, March 10th. Finally, JPMorgan Chase & Co. cut their price objective on Vital Energy from $34.00 to $23.00 and set an “underweight” rating on the stock in a research report on Thursday, March 13th. Three research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, seven have assigned a hold rating and three have issued a buy rating to the company. According to data from MarketBeat.com, the company has an average rating of “Hold” and a consensus target price of $39.54. View Our Latest Stock Analysis on Vital Energy VTLE opened at $22.48 on Tuesday. The firm has a market capitalization of $856.77 million, a P/E ratio of -4.73 and a beta of 3.07. Vital Energy has a one year low of $19.85 and a one year high of $58.30. The company has a fifty day moving average price of $28.70 and a 200-day moving average price of $29.48. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.91, a current ratio of 0.78 and a quick ratio of 0.67. Vital Energy ( NYSE:VTLE – Get Free Report ) last posted its earnings results on Wednesday, February 19th. The company reported $2.30 EPS for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of $2.03 by $0.27. The business had revenue of $534.37 million during the quarter, compared to analysts’ expectations of $550.90 million. Vital Energy had a positive return on equity of 9.48% and a negative net margin of 8.89%. Equities research analysts expect that Vital Energy will post 8.49 earnings per share for the current fiscal year. In other news, COO Kathryn Anne Hill sold 5,673 shares of the stock in a transaction that occurred on Tuesday, March 11th. The shares were sold at an average price of $20.73, for a total transaction of $117,601.29. Following the sale, the chief operating officer now owns 46,413 shares in the company, valued at $962,141.49. This represents a 10.89 % decrease in their ownership of the stock. The transaction was disclosed in a filing with the SEC, which is available through the SEC website . Also, EVP Mark David Denny sold 5,974 shares of Vital Energy stock in a transaction on Tuesday, March 11th. The stock was sold at an average price of $20.73, for a total value of $123,841.02. Following the completion of the sale, the executive vice president now directly owns 42,494 shares of the company’s stock, valued at approximately $880,900.62. The trade was a 12.33 % decrease in their position. The disclosure for this sale can be found here . Over the last quarter, insiders have sold 21,647 shares of company stock worth $448,742. 1.20% of the stock is currently owned by company insiders. Several hedge funds and other institutional investors have recently modified their holdings of the company. First Horizon Advisors Inc. purchased a new stake in Vital Energy during the third quarter valued at approximately $26,000. Sterling Capital Management LLC increased its holdings in Vital Energy by 805.9% in the 4th quarter. Sterling Capital Management LLC now owns 915 shares of the company’s stock valued at $28,000 after acquiring an additional 814 shares during the last quarter. Nisa Investment Advisors LLC boosted its position in shares of Vital Energy by 276.9% during the 4th quarter. Nisa Investment Advisors LLC now owns 1,093 shares of the company’s stock valued at $34,000 after acquiring an additional 803 shares during the last quarter. R Squared Ltd purchased a new stake in Vital Energy in the fourth quarter worth $34,000. Finally, Quarry LP purchased a new stake in shares of Vital Energy in the fourth quarter worth about $37,000. 86.54% of the stock is owned by institutional investors. ( Get Free Report )Vital Energy, Inc, an independent energy company, engages in the acquisition, exploration, and development of oil and natural gas properties in the Permian Basin of West Texas, the United States. The company was formerly known as Laredo Petroleum, Inc and changed its name to Vital Energy, Inc in January 2023.
topics: Economy, Business and Finance->business reporting and performance

author: The Times-Standard
title: Humboldt Hero | Marine veteran to be honored on Friday in Eureka - Eureka Times-Standard
text:
Name: Joe Massei and Carlos Carbajal
Service branch: Marine Corps
The December 2023 Humboldt Hero is Joe Massei, and he is sharing the spotlight with his fallen comrade in arms, Carlos Carbajal.
Anthony Joseph Massei III was born on Sept. 10, 1948, at St. Joseph Hospital in Eureka. “Joe” was raised in Eureka and graduated from St. Bernard’s Catholic School. He attended the College of the Redwoods for a semester and played football there.
Massei enlisted in the Marine Corps on Nov. 1, 1968, because he wanted to serve his country. Basic training was at the Marine Corps recruit depot in San Diego. As a private, he went to infantry training at Camp Pendelton and advanced to private 1st class. On deployment to Vietnam, he advanced to lance corporal and then corporal ranking. He was a 0311 infantry rifleman.
Joe served in Da Nang, Hue, Khe Sanh, Con Tien, Dong Ha, Quang Tri, and on the border of the demilitarized zone. During his service, Massei received a Purple Heart and numerous other awards.
Joe Massei’s brother Mike joined the Marine Corps about a year after he did. One time when Joe was at the Da Nang airport while on “R&R” in Vietnam, a person came up behind him, tapped him on the shoulder and said, “Joe, is that you?” It was his brother, Mike! The scheduled flights for both Joe and Mike were delayed about three hours, giving them precious and unexpected time to visit.
Another surprise the brothers received while in Vietnam was news their parents were expecting another child. Their baby sister Anna Marie was born while they were both still deployed.
After discharge, Massei began working at McGaraghan’s department store and met his mentor and lifelong friend Frank McGaraghan. Massei purchased a men’s wear store from McGarahan, owned a liquor display business, worked as a bodyguard, and completed his work life with Massei Logging.
Massei has been a member of the Here and Now group at the Eureka Veteran’s Center since 1987. He is a founding member of the Boys and Girls Club in Eureka, and is active in the DAV, VFW, Henderson Center Kiwanas, Sons of Italy, and Eureka Elks Club. He has been on the St. Bernard’s Crusader Athletic Board for more than 25 years and is also a Grand Knight for the Knights of Columbus Council 3103.
Friday’s recognition is also about a young Marine from San Diego named Carlos Carbajal. He served alongside Massei on the border of the DMZ in Vietnam. They were going to do mine sweeps between Dong Ha and Con Tien one morning in 1969 when Carbajal received word through the Red Cross that he had just become the father of a baby girl. Carbajal was overjoyed and asked Joe to take a picture of him to send home to his family. Two hours later, Carbajal was killed while standing five feet away from Massei.
When Joe returned home, he tried for more than 50 years and in many ways to contact Carbajal’s family, through investigators, police, public records, and messages on social media. He wanted Carbajal’s daughter, wife, and family to know the great joy it brought Carlos to know he was a father of a baby girl.
On Memorial Day this year, the Massei family received an email from Carbajal’s niece, who had found a message that Joe’s wife Mary had posted on a veterans’ website a year earlier. She let them know that Carbajal’s daughter Carla was doing well and lives in Chula Vista with her mother. Massei was able to share the photo with his family.
Carla grew up very loved and is the oldest of 30 cousins. She has three children of her own and recently became a grandmother. Carbajal has 10 siblings, all still alive, and most of whom live in the San Diego area. Carbajal’s name is on a memorial wall in one of the San Diego parks, and he is interred at Fort Rosencrans there with a beautiful view of the ocean.
The extremely close-knit extended family still gets together annually in Carbajal’s childhood home, and in May 2024, Joe Massei and his wife Mary are planning to make a trip there to visit with Carla, her mother, and all of the large and loving family.
If you go
What: Monthly Humboldt Heroes celebration.
When: Noon today
Where: 537 7th St., Eureka
Nominate a “Humboldt Hero”: “Humboldt Heroes” normally honors local veterans on the last Friday of the month. If you’d like to nominate a local veteran for recognition, or help sponsor the ongoing program, contact State Farm insurance agent Scott Hammond at 707-444-2504.

author: CTWANT
title: 女顧客開百萬豪車 試穿「4條裙子沾血跡」拒賠償｜東森新聞
text:
太惡劣！ 中國 江西 省景德鎮市有一名女子，在 服裝店 內連試了4條裙子，因為剛好 生理期 來，導致裙子上都沾了血跡，卻只願意 賠償 清潔費，氣得店家報警處理，引發爭議。
根據《綜覽新聞》報導，事情發生在4月29日，位於一間服裝店，女顧客在生理期來的時候，試穿了4條淺色裙子，結果意外沾染血跡。由於每件衣服原價約2000元人民幣（約8800元台幣），店家認為汙損衣物無法2次銷售，即使清洗也可能因心理因素，影響消費者的購買意願，因此提出用最低折扣500元人民幣（約2200元台幣），要求女顧客買下。
YT廣告
不過，女顧客認為生理期是意外，並不是她故意要損壞裙子，所以拒絕購買，並質疑店家定價的合理性，只願意支付清潔費。雙方協商未果，店家只好報警，最後4件裙子只好銷毀，不懂開得起40萬人民幣（約176萬新台幣）的車，卻不願支付這筆費用，感嘆：「開店10年了第一次遇見」。
消息一出，掀起熱烈討論，多數網友都支持店家，認為顧客應該承擔責任，「過分，必須原價買」、「還讓店家賣給別人，這是怎想的」、「非要生理期去買衣服嗎？其他時間不行嗎？」、「這必須給人家賠償了」、「這誰這麼沒道德啊！」不過也有人質疑店家，覺得銷毀衣物處置過於偏激，建議理性溝通。
•以上言論由 CTWANT 授權轉載，不代表東森新聞立場。
